Land Acknowledgement for Scarborough

The land I am standing on today is the traditional territory of many nations including the Mississaugas of the Credit, the Anishnabeg, the Chippewa, the Haudenosaunee and the Wendat peoples and is now home to many diverse First Nations, Inuit and MeÃÅtis peoples. I also acknowledge that Toronto is covered by Treaty 13 signed with the Mississaugas of the Credit, and the Williams Treaties signed with multiple Mississaugas and Chippewa bands.

Using and participating in a land acknowledgement is a way to recognize the enduring presence and resilience of Indigenous peoples in this area for time immemorial. They are also a reminder that we are all accountable to these relationships. I dedicate all of my journal entries to my daughter Katherine and every child that never returned home from residential schools in Canada through 1830 to 1996.

Meanwhile, I am grateful for your interest to learn more about my experiences socially, economically and politically in the oppressed age of times. By visiting the blog, you agree to respect Scarborough land acknowledgement and access all of its content in the same spirit. Learn more about Scarborough history

  • Demons of Peace - Sri Lanka to Ukraine

    In 1947, when the last colonizer British left Ceylon, they handed the power over to the majority of the country. The majority 85% were Sinhalese while less than 15% were Tamils. British favoured Tamils over the majority Sinhalese to lead the country for variety of reasons; however, abruptly left without any framework to run the country with 20 million people. During British occupation, Tamils enjoyed close connections to British administrations and were employed in high ranking roles. That embroiled bitter taste in the majority Sinhalese administrations. The ring wing Sinhalese majority seized power and began crushing the Tamil minority through all legal means to make Tamils secondary citizens.

    March 5, 2021 genocide
